awd_titl_txt: Mechanisms of Word Retrieval in Spoken Language Production
awd_abstract_narration:
Basic questions remain unanswered about the cognitive and neural processes that underlie language processing. One issue that all cognitive and neural theories of language processing must answer is how a speaker is able to quickly and efficiently retrieve a given word during spoken language production, from the tens of thousands of words that she knows. The goal of the proposed research activity is to test hypotheses about i) how the system resolves which word should be uttered, and ii) how the system determines when that word should be selected for speech. The proposed research activity involves a series of experiments in which response latency is used to test hypotheses about the cognitive processes involved in language production. Experiments are conducted with native English speakers at the University of Rochester (USA) as well as with native Italian Speakers at the University of Padova (Italy). In addition, an Electroencephalography (EEG) study of the processes underlying overt language production will be conducted at the University of Padova and a parallel functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) study will be conducted at the University of Rochester. These two neural studies will answer basic questions about the temporal and anatomical organization of the processes involved in retrieving words in overt speech production.

Fulfillment of the aims of this research activity will address the fundamental nature of the cognitive and neural processes that support word retrieval spoken language production. This will have implications for rehabilitation of language abilities in brain damaged patients, improvement of protocols for facilitating the acquisition of second languages, and will place important constraints on computational models of language processing. Furthermore, undergraduate and graduate students will have the opportunity to participate in an international exchange program to expand their research skills and interests.

por.por_cntn:
Language is a uniquely human ability that allows us to think and talk and listen about any topic, regardless of how connected or removed that topic may be from the present situation. The broad question that drives this research concerns how the language system works at a mechanistic level, both in terms of the types of mental processes that are involved as well as their biological basis in the brain. Specifically, spoken language production involves the rapid retrieval of abstract representations (e.g., words) and the translation or mapping of those abstract representations onto an inventory of specific motor actions that are required to articulate the word. What are the mental and neural mechanisms that allow for the efficient storage, indexing and access of words during language production? Advancing understanding of this question has deep and broad implications, not only for understanding how the human mind works, but potentially how patients may be encouraged to more effectively recover functions after brain damage, how language learners may better learn a second language, and how artificial systems may be tuned to facilitate communication with human interlocutors.

Fulfillment of the aims of this research program has advanced basic understanding of the cognitive and neural processes involved in speech production. The approach that our research team took was to implement a series of experiments in which we carefully measured the timing of word productions in different types of semantic contexts, and to pair this behavioral paradigm with functional MRI and EEG measures of neural activity. We also expanded our methods to include intra-operative direct electrical stimulation of the human brain during neurosurgery to remove tumors or treat epilepsy. The scientific results have been published in peer-reviewed journals and presented at international conferences. More broadly, this research program has served as a powerful substrate through which to reach out to lay audiences and to educate and train the next generation of globally engaged young scientists. The PIs have given a number of public lectures, educational and hands-on research opportunities for students, and supported several student exchanges between the University of Rochester and the University of Padova.
